articles.headline: British Broadcaster With Murdoch Link Admits to Hacking
articles.snippet: Britain’s hacking scandal spilled into television as Sky News, whose parent company is controlled by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, said a reporter had accessed e-mails.
articles.abstract: Britain’s hacking scandal spilled into television as Sky News, whose parent company is controlled by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, said a reporter had accessed e-mails.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Sky News, a British satellite news broadcaster whose parent company is part-owned by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, admitted Thursday that one of its reporters had hacked into e-mails on two occasions while pursuing news stories, the first time that Britain’s hacking scandal has spilled into television news.
articles.byline: By Sarah Lyall and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: Smaller Navy Ship Has a Rocky Past and Key Support
articles.snippet: In spite of soaring costs, canceled contracts and blown deadlines, the Pentagon and the Obama administration see the Littoral Combat Ship as naval warfare’s future.
articles.abstract: In spite of soaring costs, canceled contracts and blown deadlines, the Pentagon and the Obama administration see the Littoral Combat Ship as naval warfare’s future.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOBILE, Ala. — The Navy’s newest ship is designed to battle Iranian attack boats, clear mines from the Strait of Hormuz, chase down Somali pirates and keep watch on China’s warships. The ones built here even look menacing, like Darth Vader on the sea.

articles.headline: Microsoft Is Writing Checks to Fill Out Its App Store
articles.snippet: In an effort to challenge the dominance of Apple and Google, Microsoft has increased incentives for developers to create brand-name apps for its Windows Phone app store.
articles.abstract: In an effort to challenge the dominance of Apple and Google, Microsoft has increased incentives for developers to create brand-name apps for its Windows Phone app store.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nowadays, cellphones are all about apps. And Microsoft is so determined to have lots of brand-name apps for its Windows Phone app store that it is willing to pay for them.
articles.byline: By Jenna Wortham and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Low Growth in Earnings Is Expected
articles.snippet: Analysts predict that when reporting starts in earnest next week, American companies will show the slowest rate of growth in operating earnings in three years.
articles.abstract: Analysts predict that when reporting starts in earnest next week, American companies will show the slowest rate of growth in operating earnings in three years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Corporate profits have been among the brightest lights of the economic recovery, helping to lift the stock market more than 25 percent since October.

articles.headline: For Two Food Giants, Defining Fresh Fruit Is Not Cut and Dried
articles.snippet: Fresh Del Monte and Del Monte Foods are in a legal struggle over whether some fruit sold in refrigerated plastic containers is fresh or processed.
articles.abstract: Fresh Del Monte and Del Monte Foods are in a legal struggle over whether some fruit sold in refrigerated plastic containers is fresh or processed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pineapples and papayas are the weapons of choice in a global fruit fight under way in federal court in Manhattan. The point of the struggle? Deciding whether the fruit in plastic containers on refrigerated shelves in grocery store produce sections is fresh — or processed.

articles.headline: Loyalty to Syrian President Could Isolate Hezbollah
articles.snippet: Though it remains strong, Hezbollah could find itself caught up in a sectarian war between Iran, the region’s Shiite power, and Saudi Arabia, a protector of Sunni interests.
articles.abstract: Though it remains strong, Hezbollah could find itself caught up in a sectarian war between Iran, the region’s Shiite power, and Saudi Arabia, a protector of Sunni interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Mazen, a carpenter who organizes protests against President Bashar al-Assad in a suburb of Damascus, Syria, has torn down the posters of Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, that once decorated his car and shop.

articles.headline: Republican Committee Makes Big Turnaround on Fund-Raising
articles.snippet: Once teetering on the edge of bankruptcy, the Republican National Committee has accumulated large cash reserves that could give Mitt Romney a critical boost.
articles.abstract: Once teetering on the edge of bankruptcy, the Republican National Committee has accumulated large cash reserves that could give Mitt Romney a critical boost.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once teetering on the edge of bankruptcy and irrelevance, the Republican National Committee has raised more than $110 million over the past 15 months and retired more than half its debt, accumulating large cash reserves that could give Mitt Romney a critical boost later this spring as he intensifies his campaign against President Obama.

articles.headline: New Treatments to Save a Pet, but Questions About the Costs
articles.snippet: A long list of diseases that were once terminal can now be treated, but people must consider: Save a life or extend it? At what quality? At what price?
articles.abstract: A long list of diseases that were once terminal can now be treated, but people must consider: Save a life or extend it? At what quality? At what price?
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Mike Otworth’s 10-year-old chow, Tina, was given a diagnosis of lymphoma. The prospects were grim. Lymphoma, a cancer of the lymph nodes that commonly develops in older dogs, can be put into remission through chemotherapy, but tumors almost inevitably reappear within a year, and death quickly follows.

articles.headline: After a Winter of Strong Gains, Job Growth Ebbs
articles.snippet: The United States economy added a disappointing 120,000 jobs in March, the Labor Department reported on Friday, about half the gains posted in each of the preceding three months.
articles.abstract: The United States economy added a disappointing 120,000 jobs in March, the Labor Department reported on Friday, about half the gains posted in each of the preceding three months.
articles.lead_paragraph: Although signs pointed to a strengthening economy earlier this year, the jobs report on Friday came with a message: don’t get ahead of yourself.

articles.headline: Seeking an End to an Execution Law They Once Championed
articles.snippet: Two men behind Proposition 7, a tough death penalty initiative passed in California in 1978, now see it as one of the biggest mistakes they ever made.
articles.abstract: Two men behind Proposition 7, a tough death penalty initiative passed in California in 1978, now see it as one of the biggest mistakes they ever made.
articles.lead_paragraph: PLACERVILLE, Calif. — The year was 1978, and the California ballot bristled with initiatives for everything from banning gay teachers to cracking down on indoor smoking. Both lost. But one, Proposition 7, sailed through: expanding the state’s death penalty law to make it among the toughest and most far-reaching in the country.

articles.headline: For All the Furor Over Ryan’s Plan, It’s a Place to Start
articles.snippet: Representative Paul D. Ryan’s much-vilified budget proposal is clearly an opening gambit, leaving plenty of room for further hearings and negotiations.
articles.abstract: Representative Paul D. Ryan’s much-vilified budget proposal is clearly an opening gambit, leaving plenty of room for further hearings and negotiations.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, President Obama called him a social Darwinist. The conservative Club for Growth criticized him for wimping out on Medicare and military spending, and Ron Paul, the libertarian Republican, blasted him for not cutting tax rates more deeply.

articles.headline: On Jobs, Obama and Romney Argue Over Fullness of the Glass
articles.snippet: President Obama on Friday emphasized the last three months of job creation while Mitt Romney argued that Mr. Obama has been a failed economic steward.
articles.abstract: President Obama on Friday emphasized the last three months of job creation while Mitt Romney argued that Mr. Obama has been a failed economic steward.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is fast becoming a monthly rite of the election season: the Labor Department issues a statistics-laden report on the job market, and President Obama and his opponents mine the numbers for political advantage.
